history.content: Going to be pretty hard to self study 126/127. Classes themselves are hard enough.

To understand self-study, it is important to understand the idea of having a foundation or grounding in an area. Once you have a foundation, it is possible to build on it by self study. Without the foundation, it is very hard to self-study. In other words, it is easiest to self study things that build on other things that you already understand. 

What you have described about your background shows a huge gaping hole on the mathematical/conceptual side. No serious probabilistic thinking course and not nearly enough engagement with the linear-algebraic optimization perspective. It is very hard to build that foundation without taking courses, including doing the labs, seeing the synergies between the HW, lecture, and labs, etc...

What will happen if you try is that you will try to understand things through a software development lens rather than internalize the different perspectives that are needed. 

Once you have had a couple of courses in an area, it is a lot easier to self-study. For example, consider a student who has taken 162 seriously and say something else like 164, on top of mastering 61ABC. Assume they've taken 170 as well. At this point, if they were to self-study databases by reading and then doing for themselves the projects from 186 type courses, and then making up their own projects and doing them --- they would be pretty successful. Similarly for teaching themselves security or networking. It will take more effort to self-study than to take a course (that's always going to be the case --- that's why we have courses), but it is doable. When people say self-study, they usually mean something less --- self-studying to fill gaps as needed. That can be easier than taking a course, because you are aiming for less. 

But imagine if someone had only taken 61A. And a bunch of math courses. And now, they want to teach themselves operating systems. What would that experience be like? They can't even program properly yet.  61A is an amazing course, but there are 6 lower division requirements for a reason including a full trilogy aimed at building software-dev related skills 61ABC.

children.subject: I'll look into the MS, thanks. I don't have much experience or exposure to ML(especially the math). It'd be fun to learn and see if I'm interested.

Gotta ask why ML? IMO, take EE 16B, 186 or EE 126 [the latter strongly recommended if you can previously get a cs internship]. Graduate and then do something like Georgia Tech's Online MS in CS, which has great ML courses, while working for a few years and building a resume up. The MS costs $7k and is pretty well regarded, and in my opinion, has a 189 alternative and then a number of great courses that go beyond that material.

history.content:
0 ML background, 2 semesters left. Haven't taken EE 16B, math 110, stat 134, cs 189, and eecs 126, 127.

got lots of classes to take and will have to avoid great ones like  186 or 168 or 161 to take eecs 126, 127. Since these are math courses and not project-based nor 168-styled lectures, my instinct says i can self study them.

but i might be wrong. any insight?
history.subject: Is it hard to self study 126 and 127
